On 02/05/2006 07:58 PM, J. B. Rainsberger apparently said:
> Jason Rogers wrote:
>
> > My point was that instead of using string-based reflection, you have a
> > collection of Adaptors that you can iterate over to get the same
> > behavior.  How do you get the adaptors?  Use a Factory.
>
> I get it; I really do. I'd like to frame my original question within the
> context of JUnit itself, and not just to bring this back on-topic.[1] A
> common way to extract test methods from JUnit (3.x) tests is to use a
> naming convention with reflection. Assume that we do not have access to
> metainformation such as annotations. How could we allow people to write
> tests without having to do the kind of double-entry I prefer not to do?
> In other words, I just want to write a test and JUnit knows it's a test,
> rather than having to tell it that. How can we do that without
> reflection? If there's a way, I want to know about it, because I'd be
> missing something valuable!
Ah-ha.  That is a case which the Adaptor-style of PluggableSelector will 
not cover, but I never claimed it would cover all cases.  FWIW: I don't 
think reflection is evil, I just prefer to avoid it if there is another 
viable-not-too-hard-to-implement solution.
>
> What I find strange in all this is that I demonstrated doing what JUnit
> does in another piece of code, and even people who use JUnit looked at
> me like I was high.[2] Why the double standard? Why does JUnit get to
> use this pattern and I don't. It's just weird, so I'm looking for an
> explanation by asking the more general question, "What's so bad about
> Pluggable Selector?"
To answer the question -- nothing.
